history.content:
I think it's neceesary and I would do it over the summer 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

If Math 104 is the one gives you mathematical maturity, I'll say CS 162 is the one gives you CS maturity. Especially when one might touch the "engineering" part rather than doing "lofty" (there is no negative connotation here; just to illustrate the high-level data science operations) statistics or tableau visualization, I think CS 162 is really helpful.
I think it's neceesary and I would do it over the summer

<md>DS Major here. Given the new enrollment policy, it seems that this summer will be the last chance for a non-CS major to take CS 162 (I'm in 61C this semester). 

Now, 61C was quite interesting, and upon further exploration/research I'd like to be able to at least try out careers like data engineering / ML Operations, even though being a data scientist was my end goal when I declared the DS major. 

I wasn't worried about 162 'till now since it's rarely needed for data science work, but if I ever do ML Ops or Data Engineering, will I need it? If it matters, I do plan on taking CS 161 / 186 (which are open to CS minors). If 162 will be necessary, is it worth to take it over the summer - with the opportunity cost being prepping for junior year recruiting (e.g. leetcode / learning new tech / project / doing well in my part-time internship)? 

The alternate plan was taking some kind of online OS Course [like this one](https://www.educative.io/courses/operating-systems-virtualization-concurrency-persistence) for the conceptual knowledge but I'm wondering if not being able to put "Operating Systems" as a course I took on my resume will hurt me. 

Thanks!</md>
history.subject: How important is CS 162 for ML Ops?
